qas.question: What is the Scheinergrade system used for?

answers.text: comparing the speeds of plates used for astronomical photography

qas.question: What is the range of Scheiner speeds?
Approximately how many degrees indicate double the sensitivity?
What was the second use of the Scheinergrade system?
What did an increment of 1 degree Sch. correspond to?
What was 20 degrees Sch. indicative of?
What measured the visible darkening of a developing photograph?
When did the Scheinergrade system become outdated?

context: <b8_0>The Scheinergrade (Sch.) system<b8_0/> was devised by <a0_0>the German astronomer Julius Scheiner<a0_0/> (1858–1913) in <b9_0>1894<b9_0/> originally as a method of <a1_0>comparing the speeds of plates used for <b5_0>astronomical photography<b5_0/><a1_0/>. Scheiner's system rated <a2_0>the speed of a plate<a2_0/> by the least exposure to produce a visible darkening upon development. Speed was expressed in degrees Scheiner, originally ranging <a3_0>from 1° Sch. to 20° Sch<a3_0/>., where an increment of 19° Sch. corresponded to <b7_0>a hundredfold increase in sensitivity<b7_0/>, which meant that <a4_0>an increment of 3° Sch<a4_0/>. came close to <b6_0>a doubling of sensitivity<b6_0/>.
